comment_text: When I boarded the USS Toledo I did not know I was going to be given the opportunity to crawl down a torpedo tube. Honestly I was thinking I would have a conversation with someone about the periscope or something but it did not occur to me that when you are under the ice you cannot use the periscope. When they asked me if I wanted to see a torpedo tube I didn’t realized I had no clue how they worked. Most people overlook this seemingly simple system, but when you take a moment and analyze it you will realize it is quite complicated. I hope this is the level of detail you were hoping for in the submarine series, because this is what gets me excited. I haven’t decided which video is next but I’ll tell you this, I did not know one of the methods they use on board to make oxygen. Anyways, thank you for watching the series and please consider subscribing if you feel like this is worthy of your time. I don’t know if you’re the type of person that likes to share videos with other people, but I would appreciate it if you could pass the submarine series on to a friend or two. As always, I would like to express my gratitude to people who support Smarter every day on Patreon at http://www.patreon.com/SmarterEveryDay . I am thankful for the support, and the next video has a special surprise for you, the Patrons.

It looks like you had a great time on board.  Thank you very much for sharing the perspective, especially where the submarine force has opened for women to serve as well.  I look forward to the day when women serve as Commanding Officers and Submarine Squadron Commanders.  I was on USS Boston (SSN-703) from 1983 to 1986, shortly after it was commissioned.  I was in the second Naval Academy class that had women as well.  I never took the opportunity to crawl down the torpedo tube.  One of my fellow classmates and shipmates on Boston was Frank Caldwell.  He is still serving on active duty, nearly 41 years after graduation.  He is now Admiral Caldwell, Director of Naval Reactors.  We had our interviews with Admiral Rickover on the same day.  It was fun for me because I had my jaws wired shut after surgery a few weeks beforehand.
Why not load torpedos in the same way they go out?

In years past SEALS would crawl into the tube--the tube was flooded--the outer door opened--and they would swim out--silent and unseen. BUT---during the invasion of Grenada two SEALS entered the tube--it was flooded and for some undisclosed reason the outer door would not open--trapping them in the tube. They both drowned. I understand this method of insertion is no longer used.

A buddy of mine was stationed on a nuke sub for awhile. He told me a story about how, as a new plebe enlisted guy, he was told to go into the torpedo tubes with a toilet brush and "polish" the walls. Once he got into one of them and crawled to the end to start scrubbing, somebody closed and locked the inner door, then opened the outer door of the torpedo tube (which i guess usually only happens when they are getting ready to fire). He totally freaked out and started screaming, until a few moments later they opened the door and let him out, laughing at him. Apparently it was some kind of initiation tradition that they do to the new guys. Sounds terrifying. Better him than me.

You forgot to mention that the Navy will occasionally 'fire' a diver out of the torpedo tube; and sometimes missle tube, (which was your recovery!) Naval trained divers (Navy Hard Hats, Seals and Recon Marines (my case) enter and during the flooding of the tube, take a gulp of air and are deployed in a 'swim out'. They then swim to the surface in a free ascent (no air or rebreathers) blowing out as you go all the way (so that you don't embolize!) The Navy would sometimes announce 'prepare to fire special munitions!' The guys laughed at us (but we were the only ones who saw the moon during the hop!) If something goes wrong, well, they told us they would most likely try to recover the body... It was my honor Navy, Love ya' ('till Death and beyond!)

One of the things I love about Destin is that simple phrase, "My understanding is..." It's genius. It explains to someone that you have an interest in whatever is being discussed, and that you know at least a little about it. Yet at the same time it suggests that you'd like to know more, you're open to being corrected, and you acknowledge that they know more than you and that you're cool with that fact. Those three words are a fantastic tool for opening really worthwhile dialogue. I'm going to strive to use them a lot more in my life.

12:58 isn’t there a problem if the auxiliary tank meant to hold the mass of the water from the tube? Once the torpedo leaves the tube and assuming it’s neutrally buoyant, the mass of water that it displaced must be equal to the torpedo’s mass. So, when the impulse tank empties water to launch the torpedo, the mass of the water that was used to launch the torpedo must be equal to that of the torpedo. This would mean that the submarine bears the weight of an extra torpedo as water in the impulse tank, and if this tank empties then it must also simultaneously be refilled in order to maintain neutral buoyancy.

So my question is, does the impulse tank have a constant flow of water INTO itself as it pumps water OUT of the tank to the torpedo tube? Because, if the mass inside the impulse tank is sealed from external seawater this means that the submarine experiences a net loss of mass as the torpedo is fired out. The submarine loses the mass of the torpedo, and the amount of water inside of the impulse tank stays constant, resulting in an imbalance. The only way I can think of to correct this imbalance is to fill up the impulse tank with the mass of the torpedo that was fired out.

@SMARTEREVERYDAY Destin just wanted to thank you for all the great content all these years! I'm really enjoying the submarine series, my kid brother spent 5 years on the Ohio. I wish my uncle was alive to meet you, as your backgrounds are similar and I can only imagine the stories you'd tell each other. I've clipped a bit of his obituary here:

Donald P. Hanrahan, of Indian Wells, passed away on February 27, 2019. He graduated Manhattan College in Riverdale, N.Y., with a bachelors in electrical engineering in 1959. Upon graduation he worked for Hazeltine Corporation. At Hazeltine Don designed many projects for NASA, including the design of the electronics control system for the " moon buggy", the Lunar Rover used on Apollo 15. He was responsible for the electronic design of the display system for the FAA air traffic control system, the Mariner C Solar Plasma detector on its journey to Mars, the Identification system for the SAM - D Missile system. Don did research in high-speed digital logic, as well as many other interesting projects. In 1975 Don went to work for Ford Aerospace in Newport Beach, where he designed missile electronics on many programs, for the Air Force, Navy and US Army including the design of support equipment for these systems. Retirement was in 1992. Don and Jean traveled wide and often, visiting all of the continents (except Antarctica (too cold) and more than 120 countries.

Unfortunately the high IQ did not extend to my DNA. I too work for the government, but at a County 9-1-1 center, no Smithsonian legacy for me! Thanks again for helping me expand my brain.

When I was a U.S. Marine stationed at Naval Sub Base Bangor WA, I had the opportunity to go on board an Ohio Class submarine to take a tour and have lunch. After getting on board, the excitement wore off rather quickly as a feeling of claustrophobia started to set in. Watching this video made me realize the size and space difference of a Ohio class ballistic missile sub to that of a fast attack submarine. Even though I gave sailors a hard time, I had respect for what sailors (especially submariners) did. I thought us Marines were crazy but it takes a special type of crazy to be under the water for 3-5 months and with so limited space. Great and very informative video. Semper Fi.

Don't mean to be a jerk but you missed a crucial point when explaining the tube. You said the sub has a fixed amount of air but they don't. They continually make air from the sea water. After the salt is filter out and you are left with pure H20, they then use electrolysis to spit the hydrogen and oxygen, then retain the oxygen and throw the hydrogen overboard.

As info, a torpedo is not without bouyancy, because not only changes the pressure according to depht, but the water weights diffently according to the amount of salt. Submarines have a multitude of tanks all across to pump up with outside water to stay at perfect bouyancy at all times.

Hey @SmarterEveryDay - amazing video, I'm personally very passionate about submarines and this is an amazing set on informative videos!
Just something I need to mention: You were incorrect about the air supply in a nuclear submarine being limited.
In diesel/petrol submarines, absolutely air is a factor: although it isn't a great risk because cruising depth still allows the engine/air snorkel to be above seawater.
However on a nuclear submarine, the nuclear engine actually CREATES oxygen. As a byproduct of the engine operation, water as H2O can be separated into Hydrogen (which is expelled
or pressurized in Hydrogen tanks) and oxygen which is put back into the air filtration system. The air supply on a nuclear submarine with an operational engine is hypothetically infinite.
Hope this helps!

On the topic of Torpedo reloading, If the poster sees this comment, have you by any chance read/know about the Uboat captain Reinhard "Teddy" Suhren? During active patrol during ww2 he had crossed paths with a returning Uboat ( Aside: Captained by one of his old Superiors whom by this time Teddy has now surpassed his tonnage sank and was decorated with the Knights Cross ) Whose captain had succumbed to an illness. Suhren had managed to make contact and requested the remaining eels from the returning boat. At sea, in the middle of the Atlantic, the crews of two Uboats attached life vests and make-shift buoyancy devices and floated the eels from one boat to the other, Suhren would sink the aft section of his boat, float the eel  over the reloading hatch and then surface the boat again so that it "catches" the torpedo in the reloading crane. Then lower it down into the ship and repeat. As far as my memory goes from the book and other sources between 10-12 Torpedoes were loaded in this way with only 3 slipping from the floatation devices and down to the deep.

Interesting hypothesis about the torpedo being neutrally buoyant in order not to shift the buoyancy of the ship when the torpedo is fired, Destin. I assume neutral buoyancy is an important feature of a torpedo to ensure its maneuverability in the water after it has left the tube. Considering the relatively small mass of the torpedo compared to the submarine, the effect of a positive or negative buoyancy of the torpedo on the vessel is limited. I also assume the submarine is able to handle changes to its buoyancy caused eg. by missile launches. Does anyone know about this?

When Destin finally reached the end of the tube, he immediately noticed the inscriptions.
- Hey uh, I see I'm not the first one here!
-That's correct sir
-Wait, why does it say "The journey ends here"?
-Because it does, sir
-What do you mea...
Suddenly the latch closed and Destin found himself in pitch darkness. He immediately started crawling back and yelled "That's a good prank boys, I'm not gonna forget it!" but no one responded. After finally reaching the latch, he kicked it gently. Ok! I'm ready to come out, you can open it! Again, no response. He kicked the latch once more, much harder this time. An abrupt loud noise made his ears ring. They're finally opening it - he thought, but the darkness didn't subside. A feeling of shivering cold pierced through his body and made him panic. Destin kicked and screamed on top of his lungs, yet the ice-cold water kept slowly filling up the chamber. The only thing he could do was take a deep breath and wait. It felt like a thousand sharp needles pricked into every inch of his body. He heard another noise, this time muffled by the water but still loud enough to make him twitch. For some reason, it was getting harder and harder to keep the air inside his lungs. Something was trying to squeeze it out of him. Being an engineer, Destin came to the understanding that indeed, he hadn't become smart enough, then surrendered to the pressure.

Something to note about the neutral buoyancy comment: the volume an object occupies while it is in the submarine does not matter and only the weight matters.  The reason being is that the pressure vessel of the submarine is the only volume experiencing a buoyancy force (i.e. the seawater is displaced by only the pressure vessel and some of the external structures).  The pressure vessel is roughly a fixed size, so anything that is within the vessel has no impact on the buoyant forces.  To not sink, the submarine actively manages the weight of the boat via ballast systems, so as long as the submarine can expel enough weight, anything that fits in the vessel can be brought on board and the boat is neutral.  Once a weight leaves the boat, it must also be accounted for as the ship is now lighter than that weight, so sea water must be brought on board.  If the object in question was neutrally buoyant, the same volume of water as the object is brought on board.

OBTW, you violated one of the cardinal rules of submariners; You NEVER say "close" as in 'close the valve', you say "Shut". "Close" sounds too similar to "Blow", which is the command to "Blow Ballast Tanks" and that pushes 4,500 P.S.I. air into the ship's ballast tanks and you'd pop up to the surface like a cork - which is not good if you're trying to stay undetected! And would 'spoil the Captain's day'. Hope you enjoyed the experience - I spent several years on a Poseidon nuclear missile sub during the Cold War.

OK, but, (dunno if you were being misinformed on purpose)

A: Of course torpedoes are neutral bouyancy. If they weren't as soon as you fired them they'd float to the surface or sink to the bottom. The only way to stop that would be to swim the thing level and that costs you distance and speed.

B: Submarines don't have a problem with running out of air - they make their own with electrolysis. The reason they keep the compressed air on board is because dumping air makes a lot of noise. So does shooting a torpedo, of course, but air takes a lot longer to get to the surface and is very noisy the whole time you're doing it, and it's not like they're not trying very hard to reduce all noise everywhere.

C: Water doesn't compress, the reason for the equalising vent isn't to set the same pressure inside and outside the tube - they are the same as soon as it's full, it's to match salinity and temperature so the torpedo can understand its target data once it's off the wire.

D: You didn't mention the wire?! That's gotta be one of the more mind-bending things about the ADCAP, thirty miles of cable being strung out the back of the fish, constantly spooling through the tube...

E: i think I might have been tempted to mention that the tubes can be configured for swim-out mode for divers as, well, might be fairly claustrophobey in there when the tube is dry, just trying to imagine doing that when it's full of ice cold water, you're wearing an aqualung and there are no lights, that's brown water time, at least for me.

Watching the episode of crawling down the torpedo tube brought back memories of being a RADCON during the refueling of USS Enterprise (CVN-65) at Newport News Shipbuilding.  I had to take rad measurements in the makeup feedwater tank, with sits under the reactor.  It is like a maze of passages so it won't be just a large open vessel of water, all the passages prevent the water sloshing.  It is narrow and pitch black, the hardest part being the backwards bellycrawl around corners.  If you catch an extension cord or your lightbulb burns out in your drop light, it is the darkest dark you can imagine.  Jokes of being locked in and finding the remains of radcons who made a cruise when locked in the tanks were common.  Not something I would want to do often, but it was fascinating!

The Mk. 48 torpedo is actually really cool. It carries a 650 lb (290 kg) warhead comprised of a high explosive (I'm not sure which compound is used.) The most advanced variant of the torpedo, the Mk. 48 ADCAP Mod 7 (CBASS), or Common Broadband Advanced Sonar System, uses an active sonar to track its target. The Mod 7 is optimized for both deep water and littoral situations, and can achieve a top speed of 55 knots. The Mod 7 has countermeasures to protect against interception, and retains the noise isolation from the Mod 6, which makes the torpedo harder to detect.

A Mod 7 CBASS was fired by an Austrialian Collins-Class submarine, the HMAS Waller, which was the torpedo that sunk the test target in the 2008 RIMPAC exercise.

Destin, as a Cold War veteran, this journey is by far one of the smarter look into the inner sanctum of Silent Service. I've seen many, and while they all share many of the same topics, by far they lacked the human element insofar as personalizing the experience-- for the crew, and your audience. This saga has given more depth in three short video installments than the myriad of previous documentaries. Two thumbs up! I would encourage each additional video installment to bring more of this to the front, create that immersion that your viewers can come away feeling they were there, virtually of course, and yet feel the content wasn't just another "sub tour", but an actual "sub sandwich", full of humanity, personality, and content.

My grandfather retired Navy as LCDR, buried in Hawaii, and raised me in the Islands. One of my most favorite activities was him taking me out to the base and spending time in the sub museum, a mock setup of a section of a sub, complete with a periscope. I spent countless hours looking through it, across the base. This was decades ago, and on one occasion, my grandfather got me into an actual sub for a short tour while at Pearl.

While I served in Ordnance in US Army (missiles), it was either-or for me, and I chose to be land-lover. I don't regret that decision. The closest I ever got to seeing inside of a real sub was when I was less than 10 years old.

All this to say, bringing your journey to life has fulfilled a life long goal of seeing the Silent Service as never before.

Thank you.

ADDENDUM

Actually, as per your comment above, I believe that the sub can make more air from the 02 in the water.... Additionally, just like in space, the real problem is the build up of C02 from the crew as well as making sure air moves around to and from every corner of the sub so you don't have pockets of air whose composition (ratio of C02 vs O2) is not consistent with human requirements. For me, the fascination is how technology and engineering addresses these unique "sealed systems" (or mostly sealed).

The highly trained, highly disciplined, very serious Navy personnel was also interesting. Their demeanor drives home that they work and live in an environment that is incredibly dangerous on multiple levels and unlike in space, at least currently, this environment can quickly become more dangerous if they are in combat. I loved that they have a backup system of ropes and pulleys.

Nonetheless, AWESOME video. Very interesting.

P.s. and while everything seems cramped, crawling inside a torpedo tube would trigger at least a mild feeling of claustrophobia, even momentary, in many people.

He personally met and vetted every nuclear power officer in the Navy during his career, including the man standing to his right, Jimmy Carter, who was a Navy nuclear engineer back in the day. Apparently Mr. Carter was deemed satisfactory by Adm. Rickover and therefore permitted to serve as a nuclear officer in Rickover's beloved Navy.

After one of the training dives, the youngest member of our group remarked that one of the cave passages, where we had to pause and move to one side to allow a team of exiting divers to pass (outgoing divers get the right of way), was a little “tight”. Decades ago for the Navel Underwater Test Department My Company Sundstand Aerospace won a research contract to build an electric motor for a torpedo, not a weapon but a test torpedo, 350 Hp that fit into  a 20" diameter torpedo.  From my understanding a weapons tube is a little bigger.    Great to learn about the torpedo tube.   Not the motor weight was ~ 100 lbs.  the inverter 3 phase electronics was slightly less in weight.   A fun ~ two year effort.   Note: Sundstrand now part of  UTG won the contract for the British weapon torpedo engine which I saw many on the production floor and did a very little engineering on them.   The Mark 48 is a piston motor with a swash plate to transfer force to the propellers.   Sundstrand's torpedo engine was a impulse turbine driven.  Both exhausted into the ocean.   Sundstand had worked years to develop a torpedo that didn't exhaust into the ocean.  They blew up a boiler with the admirals observing the test.  Have no idea if they solved the manufacturing problems.

0:34 Okay so pretty sure I did my math wrong.
So the left side of the ship at the focal point of the blast appears to rise upward at a rate of 3 sailor dudes per second.
I measured this by approximating the size of a person on this ship by using a reference photo of a newport-class tank lander that had people on it.
So 3 sailor dudes = 18 feet (5.48 meters) and the ship rises for about 1 second.

1 Sailor dude mass = 170 lbs / 77.1 kg
Impact Velocity = 18 ft/s or 5.48 m/s
Collision distance = 1mm (I figured maybe the ships floor could flex? Maybe a sufficiently Cro-magnoned skull could dent it)
Impact Duration = 1 second

Results from the calculator
Average Impact force = 1.161 MN / 261003 lbs or 130.5 tons
Peak Impact force = 2.321 MN / 521781 lbs or 260 tons

To me this is no different than the ship actually sitting on top of you.


There is a whole lot of things I didn't include that will probably make the number wayyyyyy less and more accurate but I'm a fool doing math I've never used.

Nuclear submarines do NOT only have the air they dive down with. Yes their propulsion systems are air independent but also their nuclear power plants offer a large amount of power to produce onboard Oxygen.
Wikipedia: " Oxygen in submarines is produced by putting sea water through a process of electrolysis. Submarines typically have a couple of big oxygen tanks as well, used to quickly raise oxygen concentration if the system fails."

Deeply, Deeply cool Destin,
Only thing I recognised as a mostly civilian aircraft engineer were the Teflon blocks and rub strips, some marine grease, ( cleaned up the excess too!!!) and the judicious use of Graphite dry spray lubricant... other than that... At least you have room to move around lol...
No-one reads comments, so I'll waffle for a bit... Bored as anyway.. lock down in Aus.. meh..
Anyhoo..
The Tube has more room than many aircraft fuel tanks I've been inside of... lol...
Picture this... if you will....
Going in there with full closed face, positive pressure "on demand" breathing equipment... things get so much more tighter... then you get stuck with your left elbow against your left temple and your entire right arm locked against the side of your body...going through a baffle... 90 degrees from your intended route, meanwhile your legs can't find a frame, rib or any sort of structure, to at least flick an ankle movement out of, (Grrr moment!!) to move 3" to pry yourself free... (Those reading this.. it helps very much to laugh and not panic.. you won't die. But it sets the heart racing... and those with a swear jar... will be raking it in!!!...hahaha..
Then, you get your safety standby person to come in, to give your foot or butt a good shove (hand/boot, or even swift kick does the trick lol) so you can continue on your journey.. Usually to a fuel pump or a fuel quantity indicator...worse is a fuel leak.. spend hours digging up sealant... Fun all around... lol...

sigh 27.5 years of entertainment.....

Wouldn't trade it, for the best desk job paying 4 times the amount.

In all seriousness
Claustrophobia is absolutely harrowing.
As I'm in my mid 40's now it gets worse with age. I feel it sometimes but control it by focusing on my task. Breath... carry on.

In the end... Not trying to compare or even try to compete... in any way... (How could I?!, Destin, you are far beyond a level playing field in any way...! Wow...!)
Just watching this is blowing my mind..!!. Barely anyone gets to see this stuff let alone ask intelligent questions!!,

Regarding your question of what happens to the weight balance after a torpedo has been fired : There is an additional tank near the torpedo tube called a Weapon Compensation Tank, that takes in sea water to compensate for the lost weight. Torpedoes are not neutrally buoyant but have a small negative buoyancy. They maintain depth using hydrodynamic forces generated from their forward movement and control planes.

Thanks for another interesting video.
And though I'm sure it all "adds up" Your "graphical representations" doesn't quite do so !
The "initial state" as illustrated @08:25 has no water in the "auxiliary tank", how ever, in it's "post firing state" as illustrated @13:36 the "Auxiliary tank" is partially filled with water (that at least partially came from the "WRT tank").
Yea I know it's a nit pick, but if the "full cycle" was exactly as You illustration the "auxilliary tank" would keep on "changing state" for every firing. Perpetually getting more filled (from the "WRT tank") for every firing .
And I'm not suggesting that this is a real technical problem, I'm just pointing out (nit picking) that the illustration of the "cycle" either isn't quite consistent or not totally complete (cyclic).
And also @13:20, I would guess that the reason to "vent the tube of pressurised air" is more to avoid people getting "hit by the breach" when it is opened ((if it even can be opened when under pressure, which I doubt)) than it it for "fear of loosing air".
Best regards.

I never saw the way they loaded it, but i read about it on a few older forums, probably defunct by now, and to this day, i'll never understand why, aside from this method, they don't just load the armament through the way it's supposed to go out of the ship. Have a mating collar at the reloading facility of their choice, that collar clamps and seals unto the face and the armament is back fed into the system where existing mechanisms reverse load it into the magazine.


That would cut all the time it takes to load these things in half. No fiddling, not "pay attention" just automated, existing mechanisms that already function at peak efficiency for that purpose, asked to reverse the operation, so not even an issue of complication on their part. IE, no human error guard to slow the process down.


Not only that, but the whole problem of "decisions made XX years ago, affect what can be loaded today" would be rendered moot, since all it would take is a redesign of the tube and mechanisms and the payload would change according to needs. There's certainly plenty of space, and i'm 100% sure the engineers left enough "grounds" exactly for that kind of stuff. I refuse to believe the engineers of that era, would do things any other way in that regard considering the myriad of other examples of forward thinking in boat/tank/plane design.


Bear in mind, my wonder is solely a question, i'm sure there's a ton of issues that can be raised, but i just see an efficiency issue. Why load the weapon through a lot of hassle, dismantle sections of the ship, willingly expose it to enemy attacks et cetera, when all this could be done, NOT only out of sight and out of mind (the collar clamp feeding tube would not need any kind of human intervention, pure automation) but it could also be done out in the waters. You'd have a specialized ship class just for that purpose alone, feed the sub.


We have them for airplanes, IMO, a far, far, more complicated affair, why not for subs, where things can be much more simpler to do, because of the nature of the water's relative safety. And none of the things/technologies i implied are alien to us. Again, we've done all of those things, not only in air, BUT also in space, which share a lot with sub design, afaik, in the area of seals, structure, construction.


If it were up to me, i would design a sub to have the ability of stealth loading. It's a stealth ship, so it should behave in that capacity at all times, if required, not just in the theater of war.

So your comment about the torpedoes being neutrally buoyant jogged a memory from long ago (like, 1986). A memory which, if you're not a Star Trek fan, you'll be totally bored with. :)

In Star Trek: The Voyage Home, AKA Star Trek: Save the Whales, Spock has to guess the weight of the water + whales being carried by the ship. I was unable to convince ANYONE at the time that he didn't have to guess at all. Whales are more or less neutrally buoyant, and especially if you could communicate with them (which Spock had been doing) you could ask them to take just a deep enough breath to become exactly neutrally buoyant. At which point you measure the length, depth and height of the tank, take a sample of the seawater to compute density and voila, you have the EXACT weight of the whales and seawater.

...and completely eradicate a heartwarming exchange between Spock and McCoy, of course. :)

And the above is the exact same reason you can trade the torpedo for seawater and don't have to worry about changing your center of buoyancy/center of gravity whatsoever.

A live torpedo is actually slightly negatively buoyant (will sink) as you would not want a live torpedo floating around on the surface of the ocean where a ship could hit it or the "enemy" might grab it. Training torpedo's are positively buoyant (will float) so it can be reused. They are painted orange and are generally retrieved by a helicopter.

Early 1964, put in for Torpedoman school......Was sent to RM A school (radioman).....Top guy in my class, put in for submarines, sent to the Philippines for 19 months....Had to extend my enlistment for 6 months to have required 2 yrs for sub duty....FINALLY got what I put in for, just had to add 6 months....First boat, former Thresher class (now Permit class) USS DACE SSN607 for 14 months (on the river New London/Groton.....I requested any boat on the U.S. west coast), then off to the USS ALBACORE AGSS569, Portsmouth, NH (she's still there-Albacore Park) for final 8 months (grrreat boat/crew!)....Enlistment ran out May 1968 and Navy couldn't understand why I didn't re-enlist.....Hint: just ONCE send me where I put in for instead of just the opposite..... ;o)

One of the things I was hoping you would have seen is the fly by wire port. The torpedo will trail a wire behind it that’s plugged into the targeting system on the ship (mostly data from the sonar) instead of the torpedo just relying on its own systems. This method requires the external doors to remain open and the tube flooded so it cannot be reloaded. When it’s time the doors are closed,cutting the wires the tube is drained and the air pressure equalized but before another torpedo can be loaded that wire has to be cleared out of the tube.

In a fight it becomes a decision on how long to let the torpedo remain attached to and controlled by the ship and when to cut it loos and let it hunt on its own so that you can reload and be ready to fire another torpedo.

While serving my "shore duty" tour at N.S.S.F., 31 Fox Hydraulic Shop at the Submarine Base New London CT between 1994-1997 I had the privilege of working on many of the hydraulic systems of these beasts, including torpedo tube slide valves, etc... like I said, memories... BTW, I worked on her (that boat) USS Toledo while at New London. but my name is inside the Impulse Tank. Another thing, in order to slide past the tank and the tube inside the Impulse Tank to loosen up the connection between the hydraulics and the slide valve itself you have to be skinny, for the space between the wall of the tank and the tube itself is tight. I was very skinny back then, and could do it no problem... no way I could do it today...  lol...

Fun fact about the Mark48 AdCap torpedo. It isn't designed to directly impact its target to damage it. Instead, it is designed to detonate under the keel of its intended target. This creates a huge void of air under the target vessel and knocks it up - and when the target comes back down, the combination of the damage done to the keel by the explosion and the weight of the vessel falling into that void essentially just breaks the target in half. It's actually pretty darned cool to see.

When serving on submarines in the 70's the six torpedo tube sealing gaskets (rubber in nature) failed. It required eitjer dry docking or change out alongside. The powers to be opted for the latter. As the senior engineer in charge i couldn't in good faith ask one of my subordinates go to the front of the tune to remove all but 4 bolts that secured the 3" wide gasket so that the tube could later be flooded and gasket changed out by a diver outside the hull. The top 2 tubes were out of water and very eas. The bottom 2 were underwater and as the securing bolts came out the gasket bulged and water was spraying everywhere. I had a rope tied to my ankles to drag me out if the submarine starting flooding. They also had a knife if the flooding was to severe, so they could cut the rope and shut the torpedo door. Can't imagine this would happen these days with OSH considerations. Good on you for doing a crawl as an experience.

Serving on a submarine, and especially working inside a torpedo tube, is something that's exceedingly dangerous...  But doable, as long as you are Safe about it.  "Safe" makes difficult things look easy. But think about it... You're submerged, under immense water pressure and ice. With only the outer doors to keep the ocean out of the vessel.  The engineering here... and types of materials, fabrication, construction, maintenance & constant training and use are astonishing.  Again, Destin makes it look fun & easy...  But it's the outer edge of every envelope in terms of what's really going on.

Hi Destin, Watching this series makes me very nostalgic for a couple of reasons. First of all, I worked on both the Los Angeles class fast attack submarines and the Ohio class ballistic missile subs. Secondly, my father, who passed in 2009, was a Naval Academy graduate, class of 1954, and a nuclear submariner for most of his 26 year Naval career. He was a navigator, weapons officer, executive officer and commanded both a fast attack and a missile boat. He eventually became a division commander, with 7 submarines in his division and finally, a squadron commander, with 21 subs under his command. He was a great guy and is missed by many of his friends and family. His experience was at the zenith of the Cold War and he had some very interesting stories, many which he could not go into too much detail. Thanks again, you have an outstanding channel, two of my sons are huge fans as well.

How do they stop the boat pitching up when the torpedo is fired? The water to push it out and keep the tube full came from the impulse tank inside the boat, and the torpedo is now outside the boat, so the boat is down on mass. (the torpedo is neutrally buoyant, so it doesn't matter whether there is a torpedo in the flooded tube tube or just water, the full tube keeps constant mass) Unless the water to blow it out came from outside the boat, with some sort of high speed pump........

The ship has a trimming system to pump water throughout trim tanks fore and aft to keep the submarine trimmed as they release weapons and the venting system allows more water than displaced by the weapon to compensate for the changes in buoyancy.

You asked if it was neutrally buoyant, well, i just looked around for a torpedo i could get the most info on, and found a Torpedo 62, which has a length of 236 inches, and a radius of 266.5inches, and a mass of 1400kg, if we estimate it is a cylinder, that would give you a density of 1044kg/m^3, water has a density of 997 kg/m^3, accounting for the wrong shape, and possible difference in mass, it doesnt seem at all implausible for it to be neutrally buoyant

My thought when I saw the white strips on the sides and base / top of the tube..."I wonder if that is UHMW?" Ultra High Molecular Weight polyethylene...used as rub strips on automotive wheel conveyors (for example). High impact resistance, resistant to most corrosive chemicals, very low coefficient of friction, very low moisture absorption...all factors that would be useful when dealing with torpedoes.

The torp tube. Is a big squirt gun to get the thing out. Here is a cool piece of knowledge. Did you know the most effective way to use a torpedo is to explode it directly under the boat. It displaces all the water and brake the back (keel) of a surface ship. Think about it. The boat is built to be supported by the water. The keel is the back bone of a ship. When the torp explodes it’s force the ship up bending / braking the keel in an direction it’s dose not move well in. Then gravity pushes the boat back down. But there is a massive void of air. All the water has been moved. The ship has nothing to support it self on. And the keel brake the most on the way down. If you go watch the video from Destin you can see this happen to the ship.

I’m a former submarine office. One thing that might surprise people is how the torpedo sinks the surface ship. Most people probably think the torpedo hits the side of the ship and it explodes. That’s not how it works. It’s actually quite ingenious. The torpedo uses the ships own weight to break it in two by exploding below the ship. The explosion creates an air pocket below the ship. The weight of the entire ship is then only supported on its ends. It literally snaps the ship in two. It’s very effective.

The other thing that wasn’t mentioned is that the torpedo has a large spook of wire on the back. This enables the ship to change the course of the torpedo after it leaves the tube.

From my understanding the larger seawolf class subs have oversized tubes. And can flood the tube but let the torpedoe swim itself out vs being propelled by pressurized water. This is done to make the launch quieter. When you launch with pressure it causes a transient. When heard on sonar is a load ping. Letting the torp swim out makes it much quieter

I'm former Navy and am really enjoying this series. I chose not to go sub-surface because the technology I wanted to learn is pretty much useless on a sub. I wouldn't want you to "pigeon hole" your channel but it would be really cool if the Navy would give you the same opportunity to spend a few weeks on an aircraft carrier or destroyer or some other surface platform. I can't imagine you didn't learn about the Preventative Maintenance System that is an extremely important part of crew responsibility on every Navy ship and facility. If some engineer determined that keeper needed to be greased twice a day, Petty-officer Night (or someone he supervised) would be crawling into that tube twice a day ... and signing a form saying that he did.

As a Sonar man on the USS Georgia, I was luck to be able to perform this action once. I was only allowed as the Torpedo, Sonar, and Fire Control men are the torpedo loading and handling divisions.
